hedline.hl1: Clintons Still Paying the Bills For Inquiries, Statement Says

abstract.p: Annual financial statement released by Pres Clinton and First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton show financial holdings changed little in 1999 from previous year; they paid large legal bills arising from Whitewater investigation and impeachment; reported assets of $1.2 million to $5.7 million; paid $2.25 million in legal fees, but still owe $4.3 million (S)

block.p: The financial holdings of President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton changed little in 1999 from the previous year, but the president and first lady continued to pay large legal bills arising from the Whitewater investigation and impeachment.
In his annual financial statement, Mr. Clinton reported assets of $1.2 million to $5.7 million, similar to the figure for 1998. The government requires a range rather than precise numbers.

The financial holdings of President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton changed little in 1999 from the previous year, but the president and first lady continued to pay large legal bills arising from the Whitewater investigation and impeachment.
In his annual financial statement, Mr. Clinton reported assets of $1.2 million to $5.7 million, similar to the figure for 1998. The government requires a range rather than precise numbers.

The president paid $2.25 million in fees to four law firms but still owes $4.3 million, the statement said. The payments came from the Clinton Legal Expense Trust, which raises money from the public. Mr. Clinton reported them as a gift.
The Clintons' largest single holding is a blind trust valued at between $1 million and $5 million. They also have relatively small holdings in stock, bank accounts and life insurance.

The couple's income dipped slightly in 1999, to $416,639, from 1998, when they reported an adjusted gross income of $504,109. The difference came from a reduction in royalties from Mrs. Clinton's book, ''It Takes a Village.'' The Clintons have contributed all earnings from the book to charity.

The president also reported receiving $23,602 worth of gifts from individuals, including three golf drivers valued at $897 from Greg Norman, the golf pro; a collection of CD's valued at $297 from Tommy Mottola, the record industry executive; and a set of cuff links and a book worth $1,515 from Erskine B. Bowles, the former White House chief of staff.
